div.p: THE NOBLE PEASANT, A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS; AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, IN THE HAYMARKET.
DUBLIN: Printed by J. EXSHAW, for the COMPANY of BOOKSELLERS.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: FOR the eaſe and convenience of the Provincial Theatres, as well as to gratify the Curioſity of the Reader, thoſe Paſſages and Songs, which were omitted in the Repreſentation, are put between inverted Commas. Scenes, which often are tedious in the Theatre, amuſe in the Cloſet; and it would, perhaps, be an experiment not much to the advantage of moſt Theatrical Productions, to reſtore, on any Stage, Paſſages which, without great Experience, it would be difficult to give a reaſon, why they ſhould not be reſtored.

The Fable relates to Times ſo remote, that the taſk of ſupporting dialogue, in which Wit is neceſſary, and yet of not offending the manners of thoſe Times, is no eaſy one. Glory is often acquired in proportion as impediments are overcome: Far be it, however, from the Author to inſinuate in what degree he is intitled to this kind of praiſe; that Deciſion reſts with the Public, and it cannot be in hands more equitable.

Ambitious of deriving Fame from a ſource whence Fame has ſo often flowed, from Poetry, the Author has paid an attention to the Songs, which he hopes the Lovers of Poetry will approve. Should they really poſſeſs Excellence, it is ſtill to be expected it muſt oftcn remain unnoticed. The Poetical Beauties of the Songs in the Duenna are frequently overlooked, but they are not therefore the leſs beautiful. In ſome inſtances Poetry has here been obliged to give place to Situation and other Accidents, and pretends to no Charms.

To Mr. Shield, the Author of the Muſic, every Praiſe, every Reſpect is due! The univerſal Admiration he has received on this, as well as on various former occaſions, muſt give Pleaſure to every ingenuous mind: For who can forbear being happy at the proſperity of a Man, whoſe Head and whoſe Heart are equally ſuperior? The NOBLE PEASANT owes much, very much of its ſucceſs to the Genius of the Muſician. The Airs not only poſſeſs Sweetneſs and Originality, but they are learned likewiſe; and, what is far to be preferred, they have Paſſion and Enthuſiaſm: The very Accompaniments are full of theſe ineſtimable Qualities. If Friendſhip be not more than partial, the firſt Song in the third Act is, in particular, in all its Parts, worthy of the greateſt Maſter Harmony ever inſpired:
and yet, to ſingle out this Song, only, is doing great injuſtice to the reſt. There is little danger, indeed, in declaring ſuch Opinions, for every one declares the ſame.

To all thoſe whoſe Talents have contributed to the ſucceſs of this Opera, from the greateſt to the leaſt, the Author returns his Thanks. He forbears to recite Names, becauſe diſtinctions are difficult; and becauſe he cannot, without an appearance of ſeeking to flatter, mention them with all the Reſpect he wiſhes, ſhould he mention them at all.

list.item: CLYM O' THE CLOUGH, Mr. BRETT.

div.p: KNIGHTS, WARRIORS, ARCHERS, MESSENGERS, SERVANTS, HERALD.
The Scene is the Caſtle of Earl Walter, the adjacent Foreſt and the Valley. The time is ſomewhat leſs than two days.

div.head: THE NOBLE PEASANT, A COMIC OPERA.
SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene is a Foreſt—Deer ſeen at a diſtance—The Archers are hid beneath a very thick foliage—They are heard ſinging a glee, and, after ſinging a part of it, appear and finiſh it.
Enter Adam Bell, Will Cloudeſlee, Clym o' the Clough, &c. dreſſed in the old Engliſh faſhion, with their bows and arrows, ſwords, &c.

lg.l: COME, my good fellows, and quit the bower,
The Sun no longer ſeems to lour;
Your arrows bring, your bows of yew,
With ſilver tips and ſilken clue;
And let the luſty bugle horn
Tell of the death of deer forlorn:
With fatal note reſounding,
What tho' he be ſwift and bounding,
The horn, the horn, the luſty horn
Shall tell the death of deer forlorn.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Well ſaid, and well ſung, my merry hearts. But where's Leonard? Where's the valiant Stripling?—Does he not draw a good bow, Will? What think'ſt thou, Clym, isn't he a child of valour?

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: By my faith, he's no Flincher.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: It muſt be a hard crown that the Youngſter can't crack.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: How furiouſly the raſcal laid about him in the battle.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I tell thee what, Clym,—mercy forſake me if I would not rather encounter the ſheriff and all his men, than be obliged, hand to hand, to fight this Leonard.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: By the Lord, he has an arm like the claws of a Lion.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Ay, boy, and he has a Lion's heart too. Did you ſee in the fight how he brought down that termagant Dane, that man of might, that Alric—he that ſeemed determined to kill every body himſelf? How he died, grinding the duſt, and curſing his heathen Gods, to be ſo baffled by a Boy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, and, as if Leonard car'd little for ſuch a victory, he left another to take the ſpoil.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.p: Ay, prithee, Will, who was that Knight that was ſo nimble at running away with the ſlain Alric's arms? I had not ſeen him before in the battle.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Seen him!—No no—he'll take care nobody ſhall ſee him in any danger;—catch him there if you can—'Twas Earl Egbert.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Oh! what the fooliſh Braggart, that we have played pranks with him and his purſe ſo often?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay; he.—I ſaw his beaver up—I could not miſtake his unleavened face.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: But hark ye me, boys, tell me, you that can, what was the cauſe of this fray? for tho' I have been fighting, I hardly know what about.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p:
About?—About a pair of blue eyes, two roſy cheeks, ſome certain 〈◊〉 of ivory teeth, with
various items and & ceteras, all ſummed up in the word Woman.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Explain, explain.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Why thus—Anlaff, the Dane, meets, upon a certain day, with Edwitha, the daughter of Earl Walter and is amazed at her beauty—Well, Sir, finding▪ himſelf attacked by a terrible diſeaſe, called ſighing, with dangerous ſymptoms, he demands me this ſame Lady fair in marriage, that he may be able to eat his beef as heretofore. Earl Walter, however, did not chuſe his daughter ſhould be the Dane's doctor in this caſe.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Why ſo?—Zounds, Clym, haſt no religion?—Doſt not know that theſe Red-heads, theſe Carroty-poles,are Pagans?

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Damn it, I had forgot that.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: My freckle-faced gentleman takes this denial in dudgeon; and turning on his heel, vows vengeance.—Now neither Earl Walter, nor his ſon Harold, are of the cuckow breed; they won't be pecked at—ſo the iſſue of this no marriage was the battle in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: And Anlaff, inſtead of gaining a wiſe, has loſt his brother Alric.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Ay, and ſome few more—we left ſome on their backs, that wont't be in a hurry to get up.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, well, they may call us Outlaws if they pleaſe, but I ſay we are brave fellows; and if not the moſt honourable, we are at leaſt as merry as our neighbours.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Beneath the worn rock, or upon the ſhorn graſs,
Where pipes the blythe Lad, or where trips the ſweet Laſs;
By hawthorns that bloom or that bear the red berry,
In hail, rain, or ſunſhine, we are happy and merry.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When clouds ride the mountains, and winds rend the vales,
When murrains and mildews the Shepherd bewails;
If ſcanty our ſtore let us ſhare it with pleaſure,
The heart of the Brave is the cheſt of his treaſure.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: But let me tell you, my Hearts, Harold may thank US for the victory: That Anlaff, and his Redheads, and eſpecially that Alric, with his two-handed ſword, beſtirred themſelves ſo ſtoutly, that by the Lord, Lads, Harold's men were little better than Run-aways, when we came to the field.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well then—our aſſiſtance gained the battle—what now ſhall be our reward?

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Hanging on the next tree, if Earl Walter could catch us.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Why truly, my boys, there are dangerous complaints gone abroad againſt us; your fat Monks, and your lean Uſurers, have taken exception at us Forreſters, and called us Free-booters—for which reaſon the King's pardon would be a good thing.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: But how are we to get it?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Why, I have a project.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay—What is it?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I will go to the caſtle, diſguiſed like a Friar—There I ſhall learn what they ſay about the battle; and whether they will be ready to thank us for the ſervice we did them.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Thank us! why zounds they did not know it was us. Did not we all go diſguiſed?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: But we have tongues, and they underſtand Engliſh—Earl Walter is a great man at court.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: But hark ye me, Adam; ſuppoſe you ſhould be diſcovered, and there ſhould be any foul play?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: There is no danger; I have a friend there in a corner—Beſides I know how to a •• my part; I will ſing them jovial ſongs, tell them merry tales, and forgive them all their ſins, and I warrant I ſhall be a favourite in the family.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Nay, I don't fear thee, for thou art thoroughly inſtructed in the art and myſtery of eating, drinking, and wenching, and that is the trade of a Friar.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: However, I intend to go armed, and ſling my bugle horn acroſs my ſhoulder: do you watch round the ſkirts of the foreſt, and in caſe of any accident, I will wind the ſignal of good or ill ſucceſs.—But let Leonard know the ſcheme as ſoon as you ſee him—he has a true heart, and will never forſake a good cauſe.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Why to be ſure he'll fight—but he has one bad fault.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Ay!—What is that?

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Too ſcrupulous—"too conſcientious"—he would not let me rob the old miſerly Abbot of Whitby the other day—we almoſt quarrelled about it.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Oh! he has not been long among us, you know:—he'll mend.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, ſucceſs to your ſcheme.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ay—ay—ſucceſs to Friar Adam.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: We are Archers ſo ſtout and ſo good,
With hearts unacquainted with fear;
We live in the merry green wood,
And feed on the King's fallow deer.
We feed on the King's fallow deer
In ſpite of the Sheriff and law;
We ne'er from the Poor draw a tear.
But keep Monks and fat Abbots in awe.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: And ſo merry, ſo merry live we,
With hearts light as air,
We are ſtrangers to care,
All under the green wood tree.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: For Archery England is fam'd,
Expert are her ſons at the bow;
Their broad arrows often have tam'd
The rude inſults and vaunts of the Foe.
But England itſelf can't excel,
For valour and good archery,
Bold Clym o' the Clough, Adam Bell,
And William of Cloudeſlee.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: And ſo merry, ſo merry live we,
With hearts light as air,
We are ſtrangers to care,
All under the green wood tree.

div.head: SCENE II. Changes to a beautiful valley, with the proſpect of a ſuperb caſtle, in the Gothic ſtile.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Truly, Adela, I would be chearful, but memory will not let me.—I know as well as thou doſt, that ſorrow will not cure a wound; but knowing myſelf the cauſe of this unhappy broil, the chearful ſpirits which health and active youth beſtow, are all diſperſed by Fear and froward Apprehenſion. I am like a reſpited Criminal, that every moment dreads a confirmation of his ſentence.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p:
Pſhaw, Edwitha, I declare you don't deſerve your happineſs. There are hundreds of Ladies in little England, that would give their brighteſt eye thus to have the gauntlet thrown, and ſee themſelves the happy ſubject of contention, when young and valiant Knights mount neighing Steeds, and ride in bright and burniſhed armour to the field!—To hear the winding of the Bugle-horn, the clattering of the Horſes' hoofs, and the prophetic buz of victory among the Warriors! Oh! were I the beauteous Dame that could inſpire ſuch glorious ſtrife, I ſhould think of nothing but roſes and lilies, Venus and the
Graces—talk of nothing but Helen and Hector, Greeks and Trojans—read nothing but ballads of beauteous Ladies and valorous Knights, and ſing 'em in my ſleep—ſhould—Lord, I ſhould be ſo tranſported I don't know what I ſhould do.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: This, good couſin, is ſaid to divert me—but I know your heart, Adela—you do not envy, you pity me—Oh! Harold! Oh my brother! would I were aſſured of thy ſafety!
Ye rocks and caves, with deep reſounding voice,

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Did you hear, Adela?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I heard.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Once more.

sp.l: Ye rocks and caves with deep reſounding voice,

sp.speaker: Reſ.
sp.l: With deep reſounding voice.
Bid Echo, who, your haunts among,
Can mimic well the Shepherd's ſong,
Or Herdſman's hoarſer throat;

sp.speaker: Reſ.
sp.l: Or Herdſman's hoarſer throat.
Or with the feſtive Villager rejoice,
Can chirp to all the winged throng;
Can oft repeat the jolly Plough-boy's ſong;
Bid gentle Echo eaſe my grief,

sp.speaker: Reſ.
sp.l: Eaſe your grief.
And tell me is my Harold ſafe.

sp.speaker: Reſ.
sp.l: Harold's ſafe.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: This is enchantment, Adela? 'Tis ſure ſome kind Spirit ſent to comfort me.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: I can't tell how kind he may be, but I have diſcovered the Spirit. Come, come from your hiding place, Mr.—, and let us know what and who you are. [Adela goes toward a tuft of trees, from whence]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Was it you, young Swain, that with ſuch reſpondent ſweetneſs echoed me?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Ha! That's as much as to ſay, yes. [Mimics his modeſt bow.]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Such delightful melody in a poor Peaſant is ſurely wonderful.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Oh! ho!—That's as much as to ſay—No. [Mimicking.] Come, come, young man, don't be over modeſt—If heaven has given you good gifts, hold up your head and own it.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: But tell me truly—Do you know any thing of my brother's fate?—Is he—is he ſafe?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He is. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: There!—there now!—Didn't I tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And is he victorious? Is Anlaff vanquiſhed?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He is.
sp.stage: [Edwitha turns away, as if to ſuppreſs the joy that overpowers her.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: There! there!—Didn't I tell you that too? Didn't I bid you dance, and ſing, and—Here, young man—here is ſomething for your good news.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: [Bows and refuſes it.] Thank you, Lady, I am over-paid already.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Gad-a-mercy! Aye. indeed! How ſo?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: By being a welcome meſſenger to ſuch fair and gentle Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Hey-day!—A Peaſant too!—Do you mind this, Edwitha? This ſilly fellow refuſes money, and talks—I don't know how.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.p: Tell me, young Swain, where you learnt theſe happy tidings. I • it from report you ſpeak, or were you at the battle?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I was at the battle.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Were you? Oh! for heaven's ſake give us a deſcription of it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How ſhall a ſimple Peaſant, Lady, ſpeak of ſuch high deeds? Beſides, I ſaw but little of the combat.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Perhaps you joined the Combatants and fought.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mr. Young man, you are a very extraordinary kind of a perſon—What is your name?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Leonard.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: And—how many Danes might you kill yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To ſpeak of my own exploits were to undo with my tongue what I had atchieved with my arm. I and my companions came not to the field till it was late; the battle was hot, and then I fought among the reſt.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Companions! And did you go to fight for Harold and Edwitha?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: For Harold and Edwitha. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: "What ſhall I ſay?" How ſhall I thank you? But come, come young Swain, to the caſtle; and my father, Earl Walter, ſhall beſtow rewards, equal I hope to your deſerts.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The rewards I ſought are already beſtowed—Harold is victorious, and Edwitha condeſcends to approve. [Sighs.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: A ſigh, too! Obſerve his eyes, Edwitha.—If you give him any further encouragement he'll make love to you.—Well, really he is a very likely fellow. What a pity it is he is a Peaſant, Edwitha!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: It is, indeed, Adela. [Sighs.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p:
It is, indeed, Adela. [Mimicks her.] So ſo; ſigh for ſigh.—Why, Don Cupid ſeems diſpoſed to make a pretty piece of work here. [Aſide.] Come, Edwitha, it is time to be gone, I ſee.—Will you walk?—Fare you well, young man, fare you well.—Edwitha is very much obliged to you—She ſeems inclined
to like the colour of your hair too—but that the Fates and Deſtinies forbid. [ſignificantly.] And ſo you—you muſt return home again, and comfort pretty Nancy or pretty Peggy, or—ſome other neat little linſey-woolſey laſs—and you'll ſing, and play, and tell 'em a pretty tale—I warrant they'll liſten.—And, do you hear, don't—don't you be ſilly, and dream either of Paradiſe or Purgatory; but eat your curds and cream, and honour your father and mother after your old faſhion.—You underſtand me—Content is better than a down-bed, and the ſtars will be obeyed.—There is many a precious ſtone trod under foot.—Every Hero can't be Alexander—but theſe things can't be helped.—So, farewell to you.—Come, come, Edwitha.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Take this ring, young Swain; wear it in remembrance of Edwitha.—Come, Adela.—Heaven protect you, Sir, and make you victorious in battle, and fortunate in love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thanks, gentle Lady, ſweet Lady; from my heart, dear Lady, I thank you—And while one drop of blood ſhall cheriſh this poor boſom, will wear, with thankfulneſs, your favour—and ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Well, really there is ſomething very uncommon about this young man—A ruſtic dignity—a conſcious kind of humble ſuperiority—a firm ſtep—a ſteady eye—a bold front—Yes, the Warrior's character is abſolutely ſtampt upon his forehead.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And that is ſurely magnanimity.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: So have I been told, girl.

lg.l: The Hero, conſcious of his worth,
Amid tumultuous war ſedate,
Arms Rage and Danger, ſends them forth,
And ſeems to give decrees to Fate.
When Trumpets in the deafen'd ear,
With brazen throat and warlike breath,
Would drown the trembling voice of Fear,
And bid the Coward look on death;
The Hero, conſcious of his worth,
Amid tumultuous war ſedate,
Arms Rage and Danger, ſends them forth,
And ſeems to give decrees to Fate.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh, Leonard! Wherefore ſhould ſuch a mind be called ignoble!—Ungenerous and unjuſt!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: But how now, Edwitha! Why ſurely, girl, you have more wit, more pride, than poſitively to love this Peaſant! I can ſee the fellow has a handſome leg as well as you—can read the modeſt pre-eminence of his eye as quick—can conſtrue all his latent virtues as truly—What of that?—I cannot purchaſe every trinket I ſee; and there are many that, if I had them, I could not wear, becauſe—they are unfaſhionable.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: More is the pity that modeſty, courage, and virtue ſhould be out of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Very true; but this has been a pitiable ſubject ever ſince Adam wore a beard.—Conſider, Edwitha, the reſpect due to yourſelf, your father, and your—

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Nay, Adela, prithee do not miſtake me ſo widely.—Though I can ſee, and cannot but admire in a poor Peaſant, thoſe exalted virtues which firſt made men noble, yet I know my duty; I muſt worſhip nobility in its titles, and its outward honours; for ſo the free-judging world, and the haughty pride of lineal dignity, demand—and I obey.—Though my heart may lament its deſtiny, it never ſhall reproach me.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: "Why, that's my brave girl!"—And yet, methinks, there is ſomething exceedingly remantic in this ſudden way of falling in love at firſt ſight.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Nay, Adela, if it even were love, it is not at firſt ſight.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: No, indeed!—Aha! What, you are old acquaintances then!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: We never ſpoke till now; but lately he hath often croſſed my way, run before me to "open gates," chace the browzing ox, and remove the ſtraggling bramble from my path, ſeeking to be noticed, yet avoiding to be thanked. Once, too, he hung a garland on a ſtile over which I was to paſs.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Audacity!—"An enterprizing Gentleman, truly!"—But you did not touch his garland?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: No—I turned ſuddenly back to the caſtle.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: You did right—Come, come, think of theſe things but as a dream; remember the victory of your brother, and ſmile at trifles.

lg.l: Virtue bids us conquer paſſion,
Hard the victory we obtain;
Hard to vanquiſh inclination,
But the pleaſure pays the pain.
If a moment Virtue waver,
She, reſtor'd to former peace,
Proud that Vice could not enſlave her,
Feels her energy increaſe.

div.head: SCENE V. changes to the inſide of the Caſtle.
div.stage: Enter Adam Bell in a Friar's habit, followed by the Fool, Servants, &c.

lg.head: WINTER. I.
lg.l: Ere the beard of thiſtle ſails;
Ere the tadpoles wag their tales▪
When the maids with milking-pails
Doff their mits and blow their nails;
When the cottage chimney ſmokes,
And waggiſh letchers crack their jok es
By the glowing ember's light,
And fright the girls, with tale of Sprite,
Then will we, o'er ale and cakes,
Brag of feats at Autumn wakes.

lg.head: SPRING. II.
lg.l: When the ſwallows twittering ſing
Of the lovely birth of Spring;
When Bridegrooms make our three bells ring,
Ding dong ding—ding dong ding;
When the Valley's face is ſeen
Veil'd in many a ſhade of green;
When girls of huſbands nightly dream,
And jolly ſwains get clouted cream;
Then we, upon ſweet primroſe beds,
Will rant our glees and reſt our heads.

lg.head: SUMMER. III.
lg.l: When the young frog ſears the rook;
When the kine ſtand in the brook;
When ſleepy louts loſe many a crook,
And codlings drop when trees are ſhook;
When ſalt muſhrooms nightly ſpring,
And martins dip the dappled wing;
When the ſun with ſtrait-down beam
Lathers well the luſty team;
Then beneath new hay-ricks we
Will ſing with might and merry glee.

lg.head: AUTUMN. IV.
lg.l: When the ſickle and the ſcythe
Make the ruddy Farmer blythe;
When Hodge the bulky ſheaf doth writhe,
And the fat Vicar claims his tythe;
When Autumn yields her golden ſtore,
Till well-fill'd barns can hold no more;
When ripe fruits preſs the plenteous board,
And old wives cull their wintry hoard;
Then will we, when labour's o'er,
At harveſt-home our catches roar.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Though a Friar, wenches, this is my maxim—ſummer or winter, ſpring or fall, I am always merry.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why then, maſter Friar, you and I compleat the proverb, Be merry and wiſe: for you are merry, and I am wiſe.—And let me tell you, I am not the only wiſe Fool in the world.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: May be ſo—But pray you, now expel ſome of your wiſdom upon me, and tell me how Earl Walter bears this dangerous abſence of his ſon.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, with that gravity of deportment as ſhould ſeem to ſay—I defy Fate—if Misfortune come, I am no flincher—And then, Sir, he ſtrokes his beard, and endeavours to put a good face on the matter.—But I know him—he has it here—ſick of the father—Sir, between ourſelves—he has been—as melancholy!—as a Fiddle with one ſtring—as reſtleſs as a Cat in a cage—and as ſolemn as a blind Baboon on Good Friday.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: But is he naturally thus grave and ſerious?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh, no, the old gentleman is a—very good ſort of an old gentleman—when he is pleaſed—a ſociable converſable comprehenſible kind of an old lord enough—likes to have his own way—as moſt of your great lords do, I obſerve.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Ay, and little lords too.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why, yes, yes—I myſelf, ſimple as I ſtand here, ſhould like exceedingly to caſt this Fool's ſkin, and deck myſelf in the garment of Authority. To ſee underlings tremble, if I ſhould ſtamp; and look pale, if I had the tooth-ach—As to • a • l Walter, Sir, if young Harold ſhould return ſafe and ſound, in health and honour, you ſhall ſee him a—a very different man—Lively and alert as an Owl at midnight—Happy as a Lawyer in Term time, or a Phyſician in November.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.p: But what if he were vanquiſhed? How then?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Then—Why then, Sir, the old gentleman would ſit you down as mute and as motionleſs as a bell
without a clapper—as ſilent—as a bagpipe without wind, and as ſedately diſmal as a death's head upon a tomb-ſtone.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: You abound in compariſons, Maſter Motley.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes—they are part of my ſtock in trade, and I love to keep a good aſſortment.—Can you tell why the world is like a Fair?

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.p: No—

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No!—Your finger to your lip then—liſten and learn.—The world is like a Fair, becauſe—baſta—I'll turn my ſimile into a ſong.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: This world is a Fair, where the croud is bent wholly
On gew-gaws and rattles, noiſe, nonſenſe and folly;
Where higledy piggle, pell-mell and confuſion,
We're born, take a peep, die, and loſe the illuſion.
And there we ſee whirligigs, roundabouts,
Ups and Downs, Ins and Outs,
Fal lals, drums, trumpets, globes, ſceptres, and crowns;
Hot ſpiced gingerbread, and merry-go-rounds;
With wonders! wonders! and wonders! enough to make a blind man ſtare!
Oh! don't you think it a wonderful Fair?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Here are all ſorts of toys for all ranks and gradations;
Gilt ribbands for ladies! for lords—inſtallations;
Wigs firſt worn at Weſtminſter, after on May-days,
On Judge's and Chimney-ſweep's high days and play-days.
And there you ſhall ſee maſk'd faces, falſe noſes, caſtenets and ſaltboxes▪
Jack-puddings with gridirons, dukes, devils, and doxies;
With a ſtrange medley of tythe-pigs and biſhops, lawyers, bailiff, and priſons▪
Fanatic Craw-thumpers, who have many more words than reaſons,
Wiſe dogs, learned horſes, illiterate aſſes, and many other ſtrange beaſts there.
Oh! don't you think it a wonderful Fair?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: In this Fair you will find, Sir, the worſt wares are vending;
Here Knav'ry is hoarding what Folly is ſpending;
Here titles and honours are trades moſt prolific,
And gold is the one univerſal ſpecific.
And here you hear many fine promiſes in many fine ſpeeches;
But if you love liberty and property beware of ſuch leeches;
With their legerdemain tricks, Hey! Preſto! fly quick, and be gone,
They are here, there, and every where, on all ſides, and on none;
Then they ſqueeze their hats, beat their breaſts, rave, rant, cant, ſtamp, and ſtare.
Oh! don't you think it a wonderful Fair?

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Here puppet-ſhow Patriots their booths have erected,
To tell how the rights of mankind they've protected;
When in hopes to be brib'd, Sir, each man with his fellow,
Of brib'ry and ſlav'ry will bluſter and bellow.
Then it is that you ſee theſe Whirligigs, Roundabouts, Ups and Downs, Ins and Outs,
Scrambling for fal-lals, drums, trumpets, globes, ſceptres, and crowns,
Swords, maces, and woolſacks, and ſcarlet furr'd gowns.
Such wonders, wonders, and wonders, are enough to make a blind man ſtare!
Oh! don't you think it a wonderful Fair?

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Changes to an area within the caſtle walls. A march is played. Enter firſt the warriors, all in martial order, and in armour; then Earl Egbert, followed by a Dwarf bearing a huge ſword and ſhield; next Harold, who is met and embraced by Earl Walter and Edwitha; then Adam Bell and the Fool, and laſtly, Adela, with a laurel crown, followed by Virgins.—She crowns Harold, as do the Virgins Egbert, and the reſt of the Knights.—Then the following Chorus, &c.

lg.l: Behold the conqu'ring Hero's meed,
Behold his rich reward;
Who, nobly valiant, dares to bleed,
His native rights to guard.
For him the lovelieſt Virgin's hand ſhall pluck
The freſheſt laurel to adorn his brow;
For him the ſweeteſt, loudeſt chords are ſtruck,
Heroic verſe and harmony beſtow.
With rapid finger, firm and deep,
The harp, ſonorous, boldly ſweep;
Now touch the am'rous love-ſick lute,
And gently ſwell the breathing flute;
With melting airs and ſoothing ſtrains
Relieve the weary Soldier's pains.
Hither ſmiling Virgins bring
The fragrant roſe, the lily ſweet,
Gather'd from the lap of Spring,
To ſtrew beneath the Warrior's feet.
Nor yet forget to drop a pitying tear,
To grace the ever-honour'd bier
Of thoſe brave Warriors who remain
Lifeleſs, entomb'd upon the bloody plain.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Oh welcome, welcome my Harold, welcome noble Earl Egbert! How ſhall I ſpeak my joy? To ſee you thus return in ſafety and in honour, is the ſupreme of happineſs.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And to be thus received at our return, is the beſt, the moſtglorious reward—None but a ſoldier can imagine the ſtrong throbbings of the ſoldier's heart, when thoſe his arm has fought for, fly to his embraces, and pour the grateful balm of a thouſand welcomes in his wounds.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh my brother! my joys overcome me—they are exceſſive as my fears have been.—From this moment may the ſword ſleep in honour; or if fate will again call thee to the horrors of inexorable war, may'ſt thou find another, and a worthier ſubject!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A worthier, my Edwitha? the world contains not a worthier!

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: No—The world contains not a worthier; and that I will prove againſt Dane or Devil.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Will you, my lord?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I—I—He that denies it, lies and dies—he muſt digeſt ſteel.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Bleſs me!

sp.speaker: E. Eg
sp.p: I'd fight with Charlemagne and all his hoſt! ay, and conquer too, in ſuch a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: How childiſh, then, have been our fears, Edwitha.—This muſt have been an eaſy victory to ſuch a champion.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Eaſy lady!—Pardon me!—We have been in horrible danger, that's the truth.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: There is no danger to the brave, for he thinks of none.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: True Harold, when danger is preſent, the brave think only of oppoſing danger; but when it is over, 'tis their delight to recollect each perilous circumſtance.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: "To be ſure—to be ſure"—I ſhall never look on that ſword and ſhield again, but I ſhall remember the grim viſage of that terrible Alric.

div.stage: [Points to the ſword and ſhield borne by the Dwarf.]

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: What is Alric ſlain?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: The vile Pagan is dead.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: And fell by your hand, Earl Egbert?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: By mine—This right arm did the deed.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Here's a cowardly lying ſlave. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: This good ſword—was the lancet •• at let him blood—this gave vent to his foul humours—this cut his pack thread.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Put it up my Lord—it has carved you more honour than you will digeſt in a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: It is too valiant for women to look at without danger of hyſterics.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Sweet Dove of peace, at your intreaty my ſword ſhall hide its honourable face.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Let it; leſt it ſhould bluſh to hear its own praiſe. [Half aſide.]

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: For your ſake, bright Pearl of Britain, was it drawn.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I am ſorry for the occaſion, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Ha!—See how a man may be miſtaken—I ſhould ſooner have expected to have heard of the 〈…〉 being run thro' with a knitting needle, or 〈…〉
• own with the butt-end of a thread-paper.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Sirrah—you know your privilege.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, we Fools have a licence.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Dwarf.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: My Honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Watch me that Fool's mouth—if he dare utter any more malice beſtow the baſtinado—liberally—afflict him with a cudgel—grievouſly.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: What, muſt the honeſt mouth of Plaindealing be gagg'd by a broomſtick?

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: But how went the battle, Harold? was it a hard fought field?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It was my Lord; and heaven only knows what would have been the fortune of the day had not ſome freſh and unknown friends arrived juſt as the hand of the ſoldier, weary with ſlaughter, began almoſt to tire, and his heart to droop before the unremitting fury of the numerous Dane.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Thanks for that brave Harold. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Unknown friends, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes my Lord—they appeared to be Peaſants, but they foug •• like Heroes.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Do you hear this, Adela? [Aſide to Adela.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: You do I perceive, Edwitha.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Yes—yes—the—the Boors played their part. But what of that? It all availed nothing till that Alric was demoliſhed.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Was he ſo deſperate?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: He was indeed irreſiſtible—His brother Anlaſf, alone, of all the Danes, was deem'd his equal.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: You may gueſs at a workman by his tools! Dwarf.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: My Honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Advance me that ſhield above your head, and hold me out the ſword at arm's length.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: I can't, my Honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Can't—no—nor ſuch another Dwarf 〈◊〉 help thee—But I laid him low—I gave him a ſleeping powder.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Alas—I am ſorry to find this bad world ſo given to falſhood.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Falſe! What's falſe? thou general collector of crimes and Peter-pence—Thou ear of Iniquity—"Thou common ſewer of ſin," what's falſe? Did I not kill Alric? Did I not vanquiſh the Dane?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Who dare doubt it, my Lord! It were a meanneſs beyond contempt for one of your dignity to ſpeak an untruth; and it would ſtill be more vile, more deſpicable to aſſume a valour which you durſt not maintain.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: What doſt thou mean, Friar?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Your pardon, my Lord, "without offence to Earl Egbert," I intended to tell your Lordſhip that a Peaſant, whom I ſhrived this very morning, did enumerate, among other ſins that hung upon his ſoul, the death of Alric the Dane, whom he ſaid he had ſlain in battle.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: A Peaſant?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: What was this Peaſant's name?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Leonard.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My Lord, it was this Peaſant of whom I ſpoke to you before, who firſt informed Adela and me of my brother's victory!—He was one of thoſe to whom, it ſeems, the victory was greatly owing.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: A Peaſant! 'Tis ſome miſtake. Earl Egbert, receive my beſt, my warmeſt thanks.—I underſtand the ſervice you have done my houſe, and will remember it to my utmoſt power.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Nay, but it ſeems—the Friar has been Confeſſor to the man in the moon, and I did not kill Alric—Let it paſs—The fire of Etna will have vent—Melted pitch may boil over—Henceforth, I will travel into the land of the Cyclops, and exterminate Giants.—Dwarf.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: My Honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Speak—Valour muſt be tongue-tied—relate,—and ſtrike Detraction dumb—utter, and ſeal up the mouth of Envy—Whoſe ſword and ſhield are thoſe?

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Your's my Honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Whoſe were they, Imp? whoſe were they, Wren?

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Alric, the Dane's.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: And by what means do they appertain to me? which way do I inherit?

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: You took them perforce from Alric.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: You inherit illegally, if you take a man's property perforce—Your maſter has robb'd the Dane, Dwarf, and you are an accomplice. He is a great man, and may eſcape, but you are pigmy villain, and muſt be hanged, Dwarf.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: 'Tis a pleaſant conceit Fool—Ha!—ha!—It doth abate my bile—I feel my conflux of choler evaporate.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Come Harold—come Earl Egbert; within we will queſtion you further on the fortune of the field—it is our duty to give the brave an opportunity of relating their Exploits.

lg.l: From the clangor of arms to the banquet repair,
Where Plenty and Pleaſure combine;
On the boſom of Peace court the ſmiles of the Fair.
'Twill give the true zeſt to your wine.
While around the jocund Table,
Each brave Warrior takes his ſeat,
The Bard ſhall chaunt ſome ancient fable,
To th' attentive Soldier ſweet.

sp.speaker: EARL EGBERT.
sp.l: Father Friar, you'll come and ſay grace,
With your fat and pontifical face?

lg.l: Ay, ay, never fear,
Find a Friar good cheer,
And he'll find himſelf a good place.
The Dwarf and the Fool
Shall ſit both on one ſtool,
And their gibes ſhall afford you ſome ſport;
In the hall they ſhall ſing,
Till they make the roof ring,
While the morris-men dance in the court.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Soon among the motley croud,
Feſtive Mirth and Laughter loud;
Convivial Frolic, blithe and jolly,
Whoſe antics give a grace to Folly;
Sportive trick and merry tale
Shall many a happy Gueſt regale.

sp.speaker: Earl Walter.
sp.p: THE active ſpirit of your brother, Edwitha, cannot loiter in indolence. Harold and his companions are going for ſome few days to hunt on Cheviot hills. War and the chace are his delight.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Earl Egbert, I hear, remains at home, my Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: He does; detained by reſpect—by love for thee.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Love, my Lord!

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Ay, love, Edwitha.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: How, girl! ſorry.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: It is impoſſible I ever ſhould return his love.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Edwitha!—

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My ever honoured father.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: And is this the duty, this the reverence a father claims!—Indeed!—ſo prompt at diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Dear my Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: "Peace"—thou haſt almoſt angered me—What! a father, who, with ſuch anxious love and tenderneſs, for unremitting years, had cheriſhed thee in his boſom, ſo ſlightly thought of, and ſo lightly anſwered!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Pardon me, deareſt father, perhaps I am to blame.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: The reaſons for this union are many and weighty; Earl Egbert is powerful in friends and vaſſals; my enemies are numerous and revengeful; my obligations too are great, and gratitude demands—

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Do not, dear Sir, think I ſpeak with a diſobedient ſpirit,

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Peculiarities perhaps; ſay foibles; but his courage, and his virtues, are not the leſs eſtimable—Beware, Edwitha, of a refiactory and pertinacious will; cheriſh no unduteous thoughts, or unjuſt prejudices; and dread to provoke parental wrath.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Heaven forbid—No, let me ſuffer any miſfortune, any torment, rather than a dear father's diſpleaſure—Only let me intreat you farther to examine the real character of Earl Egbert; to give me time, and not precipitate me in the moſt important action of my life.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Well, my child, ſo far thy wiſhes ſhall be granted, but remember the reaſons I have urged, harbour no diſguſt againſt Earl Egbert; or if thou haſt, eraſe every unjuſt prejudice from thy thoughts, by henceforth conſidering him as thy intended huſband, which will teach thee to hold him in due eſteem.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My huſband! Earl Egbert! Let me not think, leſt I ſhould find reaſon to be convinced diſobedience here were virtue—Oh Leonard!—Alas!—it cannot—muſt not be.

lg.l: The northern Blaſt, that bleakly blows
Adown the mountain's ſnowy ſide,
The tendril bites and blights the roſe,
And withers all the valley's pride.
More fatal bites not, through the grove,
The Winter's ſharp and canker'd tooth,
Than doth the Blight of hopeleſs Love
The tender Bud of hapleſs Youth.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Verily, Dwarf, thou art but a pitiful Pigmy.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: How ſo, Fool?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Firſt, in that thou art a Dwarf, and cannot hang thy hat upon a peg without borrowing aſſiſtance from a wooden ſtool.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: That is a bleſſing, Fool; the exerciſe is good for my health, and▪will make me long-lived.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Next, becauſe thou art a holder of bridles; one that waits cap in hand while my Lord takes leave of my Lady—during which thou art obliged to ſtand bare-headed to a horſe!

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Theſe are proofs of my humility and good manners, Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: A very crouching ſpaniel, that yelps at the jingle of a bell, and the crack of a whip, would not ſubmit to thy office.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Why, Fool!

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why?—Oh ſhallow interrogation!—Would a ſpaniel, thinkeſt thou, pull off a Lord's boot becauſe he was bid? Or ride before him on a palſrey, to open gates, and turn pack-horſes out of the road? Would a ſpaniel doff his bonnet, ſcrape his foot, kiſs his fingers, and deliver a meſſage from Sir to Madam?—The horſewhip would not make him.—

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: This is ſtill more to my praiſe, Fool, ſince it proves me more obedient and docile even than a ſpaniel.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Nay then thou wilt pick praiſe out of the ſeven deadly ſins; but come, diſcloſe—tell me wherefore you, and your honourable Lord, did not go with young Harold this morning to hunt on Cheviot Hills?

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Becauſe one of us ſtays at home to make love to Edwitha.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And, like young hounds, you only hunt in couples. Verily, Dwarf, you are but an empty Pair.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Why look thee, Fool, I am ſomewhat of a Philoſopher, and am reſolved not to let thy railing make me think the worſe of my own good parts. A man who is not a yard high can ſee the ſun as diſtinctly as a Giant—A good Lacquey is better than a bad Lord—I am contented with my lot—Were all the world of my mind, there would be no Madmen, ſew Fools, and the Hangman would ſtarve for want of employment.

lg.l: Ah! tell me why ſhould ſilly man
Thus miſapply his ſhort ſojourn.
Thus waſte the life that's but a ſpan▪
The minutes that ſhall ne'er return!
If he with thankful lip would taſte
The pleaſures which around him play▪
No gloomy cloud ſhould overcaſt,
But ſunſhine deck his happy day.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'Tis not the biting wint'ry blaſt;
'Tis not the ſcorching ſummer ſky▪
'Tis not the coaſt on which he's caſt,
Or where he's born, or where ſhall die▪
No, independent quite of theſe,
The joys or anguiſh he muſt find,
No ſun can ſcorch, no froſt can freeze
The joys of a contented mind.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Ha! Very wiſe, and full of moſt ſublime ſentiment—Now I'll ſing you the ſecond part—It is as new and as true as your's, and as full of logic—Open your eyes and liſten.

lg.l: When ſwallows lay their eggs in ſnow,
And geeſe in wheat-ears build their neſts;
When roaſted crabs a hunting go,
And cats can laugh at goſſip's jeſts;
When law and conſcience are a-kin,
And pigs are learnt by note to ſqueak;
Your worſhip then ſhall ſtroke your chin,
And teach an owl to whiſtle Greek.
Till when let your wiſdom be dumb;
For ſay, man of Gotham,
What is this world?
A Tetotum,
By the finger of Folly twirl'd;
With a hey-go-up, and about we come;
While the ſun a good poſt-horſe is found,
So merrily we'll run round.
When froſt, and ſnow, and hail, and rain,
Are guided by the Almanack;
When Lapland wizards can explain
How many ſtars will fill a ſack;
When courtiers hate to be preferr'd,
And pearls are made of whitings' eyes;
Inſtructed by your worſhip's beard,
The world ſhall merry be, and wiſe.
Till when let your wiſdom be dumb;
For ſay, man of Gotham,
What is this world?
A Tetotum,
By the finger of Folly twirl'd;
With a hey-go-up, and about we come;
While the ſun a good poſt-horſe is found,
So merrily we'll run round. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. Changes to the ſkirts of the Foreſt, a dark umbrageous▪ foliage, in the back ground.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Prithee, Edwitha, do not look and ſpeak with ſuch a diſmal gravity of countenance. Mercy on me! Thou wilt be fit company for nobody ſhortly but Sextons and Pariſh-Clerks. Before I would mope in this manner, I would live on the eaſt ſide of a yew tree, ſleep in a cemetry, and wrap myſelf in a ſhroud.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What would'ſt thou have of me, girl? When contending paſſions diſturb the mind, and occupy the heart, the tongue in vain endeavours to trifle, and the lips to ſmile.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Love leads us to lab' rinths of woe;
Though roſes ſpontaneous invite,
Though Pleaſure ſeems prompt to beſtow
Each moment ſome new-ſprung delight,
Should the Virgin be tempted to taſte
The fruit that ſo blooming appears,
Her ſweets, by Imprudence debas'd▪
All melt in Contrition and Tears.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The boſom where Purity reigns
The breath of Detraction can't taint:
But ſhe who not wholly abſtains,
Shall utter in vain her complaint:
Like the Lily unable to riſe,
That's wounded and droops to its bed,
Untimely ſhe withers and dies,
And the Cypreſs ſprings over her head.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Tell me not of drooping lilies and cypreſs ſhades—Laughter and light heels are certain antidotes to ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Thou art a mad girl, Adela.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: A merry girl, you mean—Mad I ſhall never be, unleſs I were to fancy myſelf a fiddle, and go mad becauſe I could get nobody to dancy to me.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What could'ſt thou be merry, if, like me, thou wert going to be married to a Fool!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Ay by my conſcience could I.—Married to a Fool! Marry amen, and with all my heart, and the ſooner the better—Your Fool is the only manageable beaſt among a herd of huſbands. When you are angry you may vent your ſpleen in metaphor, talk treaſon in ſimile, and abuſe him by irony and allegory, and he ſhall kiſs you for being ſo kind—The greater my huſband's folly, the more apparent would my wit be.—I could mould him, lik a piece of unbaked dough, into any form.—A Fool, like a Watchman, walks always in the dark, and his wife is the lanthern by whoſe light he finds his way. Lord, girl, I could give thee my apron full of reaſons, and a handful over, why a woman ſhould marry a Fool.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I thought men of wit and underſtanding were always thy favourites.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p:
As gallants, but not as huſbands. Give 'em a little love, and a little hope before marriage, and they will ſee good ſenſe in every ſentence, wit in every antic, and Cupids hanging in cluſters at every ringlet; but the honey moon over, and all the little Loves drop as dead as ſuffocated Bees—vaniſh like Ghoſts when a candle enters. After this, my Lord becomes ſo full of wiſdom and obſervation, that one muſt ſet Diſcretion with a pair of ſcales at the door of one's mouth, to weigh Words, and detect Levities, or elſe
expect to have 'em entered in a memorandum-book, and read every Sunday after ſermon.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: By way of reproof and edification, hey girl!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Yes.—And then Sir Gravity ſeats himſelf in his Elbow-chair, and with all the conſcious dignity of Wiſdom rubs his ſhins, hems thrice, and begins.—Hem!—my dear—hem—my dear—Pſhaw, zounds! leave playing with the cat's tail, and liſten to me.—My dear—how often muſt I remind you of the neceſſity of being circumſpect in your words and actions!—Laſt Sunday was a ſe'nnight, after veſpers, being in company with the parſon of the pariſh, you aſked if Ariſtotle could talk French; and ſoon after wanted to know what was Latin for a bag-pudding.—I have told you a thouſand times, my dear, that your tongue is ſo flippant, you prattle ſo faſt, and your diſcourſe is ſuch a mixture of ſenſe and nonſenſe, that it is like reading the Proverbs of Solomon, interlined with the merry exploits of Jack the Giant-killer.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: So proceeds he—reproving me for not paring my nails properly—reading me wiſe documents concerning the milk-fever, the danger of cutting eyeteeth, and ſipping hot ſoup; together with the indecency of clambering over ſtiles, ſleeping in church, and wearing ſhort petticoats

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And what would'ſt thou do, hadſt thou one of theſe circumſpect, learned, fault-finding huſbands?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Do?—Why I would make mince-meat of Ariſtotle, put Epictetus in a pie, and ſerve up Seneca in a ſack-poſſet, that he might be choaked with his own wiſdom.

lg.l: Give me the man of ſimple ſoul,
Not prone to proud o'erweening,
Whoſe open eye can vacant roll,
And ne'er betray a meaning.
No ſolemn Sir, within whoſe looks
Live nought but wrinkles and rebukes.
Give me the man, &c.
No ſpoilt child of wit,
Every ready to ſpit
The ſpleen of his brain at who ſtands in his way,
Finding fault, when you're ſilent, with what you don't ſay.
May the Fates rather ſend me a fool,
Whom the genius of woman may rule;
Whom her rattle and tattle, caprices or kiſſes, can't teaze;
Whom the jig of a fiddle, or wit of a riddle, can pleaſe.
Give me the man, &c.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Here comes one will never die of too much wiſdom.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Ladies, the bleſſings of ſun-ſhine be upon you.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: What are theſe, Sir, beſide ripe fruit and thunder-ſhowers?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: What are thoſe?—Why they are—umph—they are—what are they, Fool?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: The Fool can't tell.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Do you walk for contemplation, Sir, or health?

sp.speaker: E. Eg
sp.p: Umph!—Marry, to ſay the truth, neither—Not but that I am ſomewhat addicted to contemplation.—But then I am apt to think about ſo many things, that at laſt I can't tell what I am thinking about.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: That's ſtrange.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: At other times I am ſo full of meditation!—that I fall faſt aſleep!—To ſay the truth, ladies, I came, ſeeing you approach ſo near the ſkirts of the foreſt, to give you protection back to the caſtle.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: We are obliged to your courage, Sir, but there is no danger.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Pardon me, bright Conſtellation, I have heard to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Yes truly, and ſo have I.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Have you?—Have you heard that theſe woods are dangerous?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: E. Eg
sp.p: How?—how?—where?—In what manner.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: This foreſt is at preſent the ſhelter of a daring band of outlaws.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Come, ladies—come, let us return.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: No, I ſhall walk a little farther; there is nothing to fear in the day-time.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: No! Let us walk a little farther then.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Indeed, Edwitha, you are miſtaken.—If Earl Egbert were not with us, I would not proceed a hundred paces farther for a king's ranſom.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Nay, we are all ſafe enough, Adela, for heaven protects the Fool and the Innocent, and the Valiant protect themſelves.
sp.stage: [A cry is heard without of "The wolf! the wolf!" they are all alarmed.]

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Mercy!—What cry is that?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Heaven defend us!

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Where?—which way?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: There, there—run, run. [Exeunt Peaſants.]

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: O Lord!—which way ſhall I run?—what will become of me?— [A ſhriek of women and children.] Oh mercy!

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.p: He's coming, he's coming—draw your ſword, my lord.—

sp.speaker: E. Eg
sp.p: I'm a deadman!— [Stands a moment confuſed, then runs behind the trees]

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
[Another ſhriek] Oh my lady! my lady! oh my poor lady! ſhe'll be devoured!— [Shout.] Ha! well ſaid, well ſaid, my brave fellow! well ſaid, my ſturdy raſcal—have a care—now—now—there—there—
again—there was a home-ſtroke—well ſaid, my boy—aha, Mr. Wolf—Huzzah! huzzah! he's dead! he's gone! it's all over with him! he's defunct! there he lies! huzzah!

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: [Peeping.] Fool!

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: He lies very ſtill.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes—he's out of breath.—But come, come—will your valiant lordſhip pleaſe to have a nearer peep at the ſavage monſter?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Are you ſure he's dead?—quite dead?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Nay, if ever he taſte mutton more, call me Sheep.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Why then—But Fool—you ſhall go firſt, and ſee if he breathes ſtill; for though he ſeem dead, he grins horribly.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I'll ſell you his teeth for ſix-pence a dozen.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: A bargain, Fool.—But don't be raſh—don't be too ventureſome—take care—go ſoftly—
sp.stage: [Keeps following, and peeping with the utmoſt caution, ſtep by ſtep.]

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Leonard, with his ſword bloody, ſupporting Edwitha,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How are you, gentle Lady?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Saſe, Sir; thanks to "your generous, to" your noble valour.—Are you wounded, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not at all, Lady,

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Do you know where is my couſin Adela?—Is ſhe out of danger?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Entirely.—I ſaw her enter a cottage a little to the left.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: You are born, Sir, to be my Deſender.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Would I were.

sp.speaker: Edw,
sp.p: "Heaven reward your magnanimity."—I was too much your debtor, Sir, before.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Say not ſo, dear Lady;—you are not, 'tis I am the debtor! To be permitted to converſe with you! To touch your beauteous hand! To hear you acknowledge you are obliged to me!—To me!—A poor and humble Peaſant! How might I hope ſuch abundant happineſs? Oh that I had been born a Prince, that I might have been ſome way worthy of you!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: You ſpeak, Sir, with paſſion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pardon me, gentle Lady—I had almoſt forgot myſelf.— [Sighs.]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I rate your virtues highly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Tell me, Lady, what would he deſerve, who, ſunk like me, in indigence and obſcurity, ſhould dare, by loving you, to make himſelf your Equal?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: "If, Sir, he had your virtues," he would deſerve more than I durſt grant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Generous Lady! But when I ſuffer a word, a wiſh to eſcape, offenſive to that purity I adore in you, may you and heaven deteſt me!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I find, Sir, you are truly noble. Tell me, then, how does it become the daughter of an ancient houſe, proud of its alliances, and jealous of its honours, to behave?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Equal to its dignities and expectations, and conſiſtent with her own worth: and he who, under the maſk of love, tempts Innocence to betray her duty, and wound her honour, is unworthy the leaſt regard of Beauty or of Virtue.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Mercy on me, Edwitha, what a terrible affair this had like to have proved.—We jeſted about wolves with that Fool to ſome purpoſe.—So, young man—what, are you here again?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Yes, Adela, and to him we owe our preſent ſafety; he killed the horrid ſavage.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p:
He!—Well, I declare if ever I write a romance, I'll call my hero Leonard.—But come, come▪ let us get away from this frightful foreſt—I ſhall
dream of wolves for this twelvemonth.—Young man, will you ſee us ſafe out of theſe territories of teeth and claws?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Well, well, give me your arm then.—Edwitha, I have left a wing for you.—Though ſtay, ſtay.—What is your name?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Leonard.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: You muſt know, Leonard—I have a very great eſteem for you—I think myſelf very much obliged to you; and though ſomewhat flippant, perhaps, as I know myſelf to be a very prudent ſenſible girl, I would fain give you a little advice, becauſe I—ſee how it is with you.—But—no—I can't ſpeak it—ſo I 'll turn it into a ſong.

lg.l: He who loves his miſtreſs truly,
Ever anxious for her fame,
Scorns to let a thought unruly
Taint his ardent gen'rous flame:
Sooner far would hopeleſs periſh,
Than indulge impure deſires,
Tho' thro' life he'll conſtant cheriſh
Gentle hopes and holy fires.
If the Lover doth not ſo,
Virgins mark him for your foe.
Ever faithful, ever tender,
Ever watchful for the day,
When his valour may defend her,
Not his cunning may betray.
Selfiſh ſnares ſo much deteſting,
If unequal love denies,
(Pity's tear alone requeſting)
He a willing martyr dies.
If the Lover doth not ſo,
Virgins mark him for your foe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh fortunate day! Unhop'd for happineſs▪ Angelic Edwitha! And have I!—have I reſcued thee from death!—But who can tell what farther danger may yet occur?—I 'll follow, and while my raviſhed eyes can trace the celeſtial Viſion, will ſtill be ready to defend her from harm. [Exit.]

div.head: SCENE VII. Changes to the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: I wiſh, Maſter Friar, you would not keep teizing me, and following me up and down, in and out, backward and forward, into every room of the houſe, a this'n.—I tell you, I don't want to have any thing to ſay to you—I don't like you.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Nay, but hear ye me, Alice, I 'll confeſs you your ſins, Alice, and enjoin you the ſweeteſt penance, Alice.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: You!—ſweet!—An old fuſty Friar.—There is nothing ſweet about you.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Alice, I have a ſweet breath, as you ſhall taſte, Alice. [Kiſſes her, ſhe ſtruggles.]

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: If you touch me again I—I 'll raiſe the houſe about your ears—an ugly, old monſter.—I declare thère is no living for theſe wicked old Friars.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: What then—all Friars are—hey, Alice—

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: All Friars are— [mimicks him]—Yes—all Friars arè—"hey, Alice." And ſo, if you offer to lay a finger on me again—"look you—here are my nails."

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: But hear you me, Mrs. Alice—you are not ſo furiouſly virtuous when you meet Adam Bell at the dark cave in the foreſt, Mrs. Alice.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Hey! [frightened.]

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Do you remember, the laſt time you ſaw him, which is now three weeks ſince, and two days, how lovingly you claſped him round the neck, and called him your dear Adam, and your ſweet Adam; and how you perſuaded him to ſwear he would marry you at Eaſter—Hey, Alice!

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Lord a' mercy!—why ſartinly you deal with Old Nick.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I can conjure a little, Mrs. Alice.—If I pleaſed I could ſhow you Adam Bell ſtanding here in this very ſpot in leſs than half a minute.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Nay, don't, don't—for goodneſs ſake, don't—For I have heard ſay, as how, when the Old One carries any body through the air, a' that'n, he always raiſes a whirlwind; and that they are ſometimes miſerably daſhed in pieces againſt a chimney or a church ſteeple.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: What—then you—you really—love Adam Bell—Hey, Alice?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Aye, do I, from the very bottom of my heart—My mother has found it out, and—

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I know what you are going to ſay—You are going to inform me how ſhe ſcolds you, and tells you Adam is an outlaw, and will come to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: As I hope to be ſaved and ſo ſhe does.—Moreover, ſhe ſays as how he does not care for me; and that he's only leading me into a fool's Paradiſe, and when he has got me there, there he'll leave me.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: And then, inſtead of Paradiſe, you'll awake in Purgatory—Hey, Mrs. Alice.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: So ſhe ſays.—However, I have a good heart on't.—She does not know my Adam.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Oh my bonny, bonny Adam Bell,
With thee I'd traverſe hill and dale;
All the day I would follow whatever befell,
To liſten at night to the tale
Of my bonny, bonny Adam Bell.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: O'er ſea or land, by night or day,
With a light heart and undaunted,
I'd trip o'er the hills and far away,
While merrily I chaunted,
Of my bonny, bonny Adam Bell,
With whom I'd traverſe hill and dale;
All the day would I follow whatever befell,
To liſten at night to the tale
Of my bonny, bonny Adam Bell.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Tho' my bed were of the graſs ſo green,
And a cold ſtone were my pillow,
I'd brave the blaſt that bites ſo keen,
Nor fear the foaming billow;
But with my bonny, bonny Adam Bell,
I'd jocund traverſe hill and dale;
All the day would I follow whatever befell,
To liſten at night to the tale
Of my bonny, bonny Adam Bell.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Well, but now—hark ye me, Mrs. Alice—you perceive I know your pranks, and ſo—you—you

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Keep your hands to yourſelf—what do you know?—I am ſure if you were the devil himſelf in the ſhape of a friar, which, for aught I can tell, you may be, you know no harm of me, except that I love Adam Bell.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: And that is harm enough, Alice.—He is a wicked fellow, and, as your mother ſays, may come to be hanged; though I have the chriſtian charity to hope he will not.—But you muſt not be coy to me, Alice—conſider, I can tell tales, Alice.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Well then, you may tell.—To be ſure you may get me turn'd away from my place, may hap, and I ſhould be very ſorry for that—But I would ſooner loſe fifty places, than be falſe-hearted to Adam Bell.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: [Very much pleaſed.] Ha, ha—well—ha, well—ha, well—ha—I—I find you—you are a true-hearted laſs, Alice, and I partly commend you, Alice.—But hark ye me, Alice—If ever you play Adam a trick with any body elſe, Alice, I'll—I'll be revenged on you for this—I'll ſurely tell him the inſtant I know it.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: You'll ſtay till you know before you tell, won't you?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Alice, yes—

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: When then I defy both you and your grandfather, old Nick.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Well, Alice, ſince it is ſo, ſay your prayers night and morning, and continue to love Adam Bell.—" 〈…〉 a great friendſhip for him."—He is a very worthy clever fellow.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Yes, ſo he is; a much cleverer than ever ſtood on the ſhanks of a friar. [Exit.]

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.p: Well ſaid, my bonny laſs;—and when I forſake thee, or uſe thee unkindly, may I never taſte the bleſſings which love and a true-hearted woman can beſtow.

lg.l: Woman! charming lovely woman,
Thy gentle ſmiles ſhall ever be
Ador'd by me,
Oh lovely woman!
For what would all the bounteous ſtores
Which Nature from her boſom pours,
Of rich and rare,
Of good, and ſweet, and fair;—
What would they be,
Depriv'd of thee,
Oh lovely, kind, enchanting woman!
Ah! who could hear the Linnet ſing,
Or ſee the beauteous tints of Spring;
Ah! who could hear, or ſee, or taſte,
If thou beyond the reach of man wert plac'd?
Oh woman! charming, lovely woman!
Thy gentle ſmiles ſhall ever be
Ador'd by me,
Oh lovely woman!

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Enter Earl Egbert with the wolf's head, his ſword drawn, and the Fool following him.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: What a horrible monſter it is, Fool!—What tuſks!

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And what do you intend to do with it, now you have been valiant enough to cut off the head of a dead Wolf?

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Preſerve it as a trophy to tell poſterity,

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: How courageouſly you ran away.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Fool,—doſt ſee▪ this purſe of gold?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes—but tactus—feeling is the beſt of the five ſenſes.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: I—did not run away from the wolf, Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh, oh! [aſide.]—Yes—yes, you did.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: I tell you, Fool, I did not—nay more—I kill'd the wolf with my own right arm.—Did—I not?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Yes I did—and you ſaw me—you were a ſpectator of the terrible combat.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No—no—no.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: No! [Plays with the purſe.]

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Well, well—then I did not—

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Hey!—egad—now I recollect—I—I believe you did, but the proof lies in the purſe, and the purſe lies in your pocket.

sp.speaker: E Egb.
sp.p: —There—take it—and ſhew your wiſdom, Fool, by praiſing my valor.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Valor! [examining the contents of the purſe] three, ſix, nine, twelve,—by the ſting in the dragon's tail St. George was a coward to you—eighteen, twenty, one, two, three—a Welſhman on St. David's▪day was never half ſo full of wrath.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Now anſwer me—How, when the wolf approached—how did I look?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Look!—terrible!—as nine taylors at one cucumber! I remember a ſong about a Knight almoſt as couragious as yourſelf: you ſhall hear.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Sir Eglamore was a valiant knight,
Fa, la, lankey down dilly.
He call'd for his ſword, and went forth to fight,
Fa, la, lankey down dilly.
He went forth to fight, as I've heard ſay▪
And when he came there he ran away. Fa, la, &c.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: A hungry wolf did tow'rd him leap, Fa, la, &c.
But he'd rather have met with a ſcore of ſheep;
Fa, la, &c.
Then he ran ſo faſt that his ſword did drop▪
And he ſcorn'd to turn back to pick it up. Fa, la, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Then there came whiſtling down the plain Fa, la, &c.
A ſurly, ſturdy, dauntleſs ſwain: Fa, la, &c.
Mean while the knight ran up a tree,
That if they ſhould fight, he the combat might ſee.
Fa, la, &c.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Oh then began a bloody fray, Fa, la, &c.
As the knight durſt not fight, he reſolv'd to pray;
Fa, la, &c.
But had you beheld Sir Eglamore,
When as he heard the ſavage roar! Fa, la, &c.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: This Peaſant did his ribs ſo roaſt, Fa, la, &c.
That Mr. Wolf gave up the ghoſt: Fa, la, &c.
So when the knight ſaw the Monſter dead,
His courage return'd, and he cut off his head.
Fa, la, &c.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p:
Hark ye, Fool—this is no jeſting matter—It is not convenient that Earl Walter ſhould know the
truth—Beſides—I ſay, Fool, I am valorous—ſet that down in your creed—believe and report it, and gold ſhall jingle in your purſe.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh, I am a very Pagan Prieſt for that—I will believe any thing, and report any thing for Gold.—But Edwitha, and that waſp, Adela, will tell a different tale.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Nay, now I find you are a dull Fool.—Let it be granted, which, conſidering their fright, is very unlikely, that they ſaw ſomebody elſe attack the wolf—he fell—What of that?—He was only ſtunned—he got up again—more enraged than ever—upon which I—ſeeing him make towards Edwitha—drew my ſword, ſet myſelf in his path, and with a ſingle ſtroke cut off his head.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: You had better do it at two—double your ſtroke—it will ſound better.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: "No matter;"—follow my directions, and your fortune is made▪ Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Ha—ſo ſhall the proverb, That Fools have fortune, be verified.—Well—ſo be it.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: My Lord—I—have—here brought—a trifling gift for your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: For me, my Lord? [coldly]

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Um—a—kind of—preſent nothing—tho' not long ſince—a terrible reality.—But thus do circumſtances change the properties of things; and thus was the ſword a circumſtance that changed theſe fangs to the mere images of Anger and Deſtruction.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord—but whoſe ſword?

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Mine—

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Your's!

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Mine—a—matter—of—ſmall moment—yet—ſomething.—The labours of Hercules were not all equally dangerous.—Let theſe poor doings be conſtrued in their plain ſenſe, and Courage ſhall ſleep contented.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Let me underſtand you, Earl Egbert.—Was it you who fought with the Wolf?

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: And killed him?

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: And killed him.—"The deed is recent and notorious."—Women, boys, and cowards did ſpeculate.—The Fool likewiſe beheld; let him impart,—"To the act of Valour let him give the garb of Truth."

sp.speaker: E Wal.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Am I doubted?—Why then, let Virtue be extinct from this vile world, and only let Fear and Falſhood flouriſh.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Amen.—So ſhall our cauſe thrive. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Pardon me, Earl Egbert, but I had been told—

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: That new moons are made of old Almanacs, perhaps. And that royal Arthur's knights were taylor's 'prentices—I claim day-light, and fifty pair of eyes, for my teſtimonies—they ſaw, and they ſhall announce.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Saw you! you yourſelf vanquiſh the wolf!

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Me—Me myſelf they ſaw, from the loopholes of hedges, and the tops of trees—The act was viſible.—The ſun was not in eclipſe, nor hid behind a wooden trencher—What! is the blood not moiſt, and ſmoking ſtill upon my ſword?

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Forgive me, noble Egbert.—The account I had heard from Adela was very different.—

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Let the Fool ſpeak; he ſaw the combat.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the Fool ſaw it—the Fool was wiſe and ran away.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Ay—The Fool ran away.—For▪ my own part—I—I retreated a few paces, 'tis true, but it was only to draw my ſword.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And put himſelf in a poſture of offence—and defence.—Had you beheld how he look'd— [burſts inton laugh.]—you would have died with laughing.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: With laughing!

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Ay—to ſee what a ſilly figure he cut—

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Silly figure! who? what? [Angrily, but ſtriking his pocket as to give the Fool hints of future reward.]

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why— [laughs; then ſtops ſuddenly] the wolf without his head to be ſure.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: But pray was there not a Peaſant, who—

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Oh, yes—yes—There was a ſturdy Hind who gave him the firſt blow.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And to ſay the truth, a deviliſh hard knock it was—I thought Mr. Wolf had been dead and gone—quite deceaſed, till Earl Egbert ſhewed me to the contrary.—But he was only ſtunned.—

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: This accounts for the miſtake.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: He got up again—more enraged than ever—upon which, the valiant Earl ſeeing him make towards Edwitha, drew his ſword, ſet himſelf in his path, and with a ſingle ſtroke—humph—hold—I forget—was it one or two ſtrokes?

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Two—two ſtrokes.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh—ah—and with two ſingle ſtrokes cut off his head.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Leave your fooling, ſirrah—Earl Egbert, I know not how to thank you.—Twice has my daughter owed her ſafety to your arm.—But ſhe ſhall acknowledge, ſhe ſhall reward your ſervices.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Why that is ſufficient, Earl Walter.—Good deeds and valiant, I find, are liable to miſconſtructions.—Envy is the ſhadow of Merit—Let it paſs.—

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, Anlaff, the Dane, with a ſtrong band, is approaching faſt to aſſault the caſtle, informed, as Rumour ſays, of the abſence of young Harold and your friends.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Anlaff! The devil he is. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Anlaff! Oh my prophetic ſpirit!—How far are they hence?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Some three hours march, as 'tis ſaid, my lord.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Fly, friend, take the ſwifteſt horſe, and uſe thy utmoſt diligence to Cheviot Hills, to inform my ſon—Relate our danger, bid him make what ſpeed he may, and we; in the mean time, will do all that deſperate men can do to repel the enemy. [Exit Meſſenger.]—Oh Earl Egbert, we now ſhall have occaſion for all our courage.

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: I wiſh I was at ſea in a cockle ſhell, with all my ſoul. [Aſide]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My Father!

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Edwitha!—haſt thou heard?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Oh my child, I tremble for thee.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Fear not for me, my father; my heart tells me you never ſhall behold Edwitha in any ſtate unworthy of yourſelf—you may ſee me die, but never debaſed.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: I foreſaw the probability of this—I warned thy brother, but he, raſh and unthinking, contemned my fears.—But wherefore do I waſte that time in complaint which might be ſo much better employed? Come, Earl Egbert, let us think about defence and dying properly. [Exit Earl Walter.]

sp.speaker: E. Egb.
sp.p: Dying properly—a very happy ſubject for contemplation truly. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Take comfort, rely on the care of heaven, my Edwitha.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: On that alone I depend for ſupport and preſervation.

div.head: FINALE.

lg.l: To man the future's unſoreſeen;
'Tis then his duty to await
The various turns of wayward ſate,
With mind unaw'd and thought ſerene.
Tho' preſent tempeſte cloud the fky,
Around the livid lightnings blaze,
Sweet innocence can yet ſupply
The ſoul reſign'd,
The conſtant mind,
Whoſe power ſupreme the raging ſtorm obeys.

div.stage: [EDWITHA and ADELA walk up the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: EGBERT.
sp.l: I find my ſears increaſe apace,
Oh, would I were in any other place.

lg.l: Did you e'er ſee a Taylor, Sir, handle his ſheers?
How he'll ſnip,
And he'll clip,
And his fury to quell,
In buckram make terrible ſlaughter;
Oft ſending vaſt remnants to hell!
Like him the fierce Dane gives no quarter,
But with blood and with battle
Will make the walls rattle
About your ears;
Would I were hid in ſome old well.

sp.l: Where is Earl Walter, who can tell?

sp.speaker: EDWITHA.
sp.l: He went good Friar hence, e'en now,
With heavy heart and clouded brow.
Ah me! where ſhall we women run!
Oh, Lady, we are all undone!

sp.speaker: EGBERT.
sp.l: Ay, ay, alack, we're all undone!

sp.speaker: ADAM.
sp.l: Hence with your daſtard doubts and fears.
Alice chear your heart, and dry your tears.

sp.speaker: ADAM and FOOL.
sp.l: Hence, then, with daſtard doubts and fears

sp.speaker: EDWITHA, ADELA, and ALICE.
sp.l: We'll chear our hearts, and dry our tears.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Who knows but heaven may on high,
Behold a ſpeedy ſuccour nigh.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Earl Walter, and afterwards Adam Bell.

sp.speaker: Earl Walter.
sp.p: THIS generous alacrity, this grateful courage, infuſes freſh vigour into my old arm, and almoſt makes me young again—almoſt teaches me to hope impoſſibilities.—Alas it is in vain! The revengeful Dane will ſoon arrive, and ſatiate himſelf with ſlaughter. [Enter Adam Bell.] What here ſtill, holy Friar? Why doſt thou not fly this place of death?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I mean to ſtay with you.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: To ſtay with me?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord; to fight with you, to die with you, ſhould it be neceſſary, but I have better hopes.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Whence? How, good Friar?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: My Lord, you heard the teſtimony your ſon gave to the valour of certain Peaſants, by whoſe aſſiſtance the late battle was turned againſt the Dane.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Ay, I heard it with ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Thoſe Peaſants might again do you good ſervice, if—

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: If what? Who are they? what are they? where are they?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: They are men who have greater cauſe to live in fear than expectation from the houſe of Earl Walter.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Fear! you ſpeak in riddles—explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: They are the Outlaws whom you have ſo often threatened to purſue to death and ignominy, but who wiſh to obtain your ſavour, and by your means the pardon of offended Majeſty.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: And do they intend to reform?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: They are ſtedfaſt in that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: But who ſhall tell them of my diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I will my Lord, and quickly.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Will you, Friar?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I will, my good Lord, tho' no Friar.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: But one of the chief of thoſe bold Outlaws—Adam Bell—
sp.stage: [Throws off his diſguiſe, and appears armed.

sp.speaker: E Wal.
sp.p: Adam Bell! And where—where are your aſſociates?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Waiting within the ſound of this [Points to his bugle born] This ſhall preſently collect a ſet of brave fellows, who at leaſt will do ſomething toward protecting the caſtle from the Dane till the arrival of your ſon.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Miraculous! unhoped relief!—Come then—draw your companions hither—believe me you will not find me forgetful of a ſervice like this.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: My Lord, We neither doubt your honour nor your generoſity: uſe us but according to the nobleneſs of your own nature, and our zeal in your defence, and we ſhall be ſully ſatisfied. [Exit E. W.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Dear Adam, I never was ſo rejoiced to ſee thee in all my life.—Are your friends all ſafe within the caſtle?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: All—and all are yet too few—The Dane is arrived fluſh of men, and boiling with revenge for the loſs of his brother.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Well, I don't fear 'em now Adam—you ſhall be our Hector to fight the Trojans.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: The Trojans, Alice! What doſt thou know about the Trojans?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Know!—why a great deal—My grandfather uſed to tell me endleſs ſtories about the Trojan Greeks.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Oh yes—It was all his delight—and ſo of a night he would ſit and reharſe ſuch things—About the rape of Troy, and the deſtruction of the Greeks, and the burning of Fair Helen—and about Neſtor, that had ſeventy ſons—and how fifty men crept into a horſe's belly.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Surely!

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: And then he ſaid there was ſuch terrible battles between Hector and Alexander, and Killies and Hecuba.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Well, well, Alice, we'll fight like Greeks and Trojans true I warrant.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Yes, I have a good heart on't now, Adam—There be you and your companions, and Earl Egbert, and—

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Earl Egbert, Alice! Earl Egbert is a Braggart, a Coward—

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: A Coward!

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Ay, Alice—A falſe lying Coward—that would run from his own ſhadow, if on lifting his arm it appeared in a threatening poſture.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Mercy! Why he talks as if he could live upon Lion's hearts, and broil them himſelf.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Yes he has talked too much—he will repent his talking ere long. But come Alice, this is no time for talking with me—I muſt give thee a kiſs for comfort, and then to the battle.

lg.l: Inur'd to wars and rude alarms,
Unſhaken amid the din of arms,
We ſtartle not at Terror's diſmal yells:
The ſhouts and clangors of the foe,
The horrors Death and Danger know,
But animate the heart where Courage dwells.

sp.speaker: Alice.
