sp.p: Heaven be with thee, Adam—I love thee, and in ſpite of all my mother can ſay againſt thee, ever ſhall love thee.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: How can my mother chide my love?
How can ſhe frown and ſcold me?
How can ſhe ſay he'll faithleſs prove,
As ſhe has often told me!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Ah! did ſhe know his winning wiles!
Ah! could ſhe taſte ſuch bliſſes!
And heard his oaths, and ſaw his ſmiles,
And felt his precious kiſſes!
She would not ſurely chide my love,
She would not frown and ſcold me;
She would not ſay he'll faithleſs prove,
As ſhe has often told me.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: His lips are like the ſugar-pea,
His tongue is dipt in honey;
His words are dearer far to me
Than waggon loads of money!
Then do not, mother, chide my love,
Then do not frown and ſcold me;
Then do not ſay he'll faithleſs prove,
As you have often told me.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Prithee, Fool, good Fool, afford me conſolation—give me comfort, moſt ſage Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I can't—cannot—unleſs I could give you wings—There is no eſcaping—bolts and bars forbid—ſtone walls are not to be moved with fine ſpeeches—Rhetoric is loſt—eloquence thrown away upon 'em—a key is your only Counſellor in this caſe.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Is it not very ſtrange, Fool, that I ſhould be as valiant as Alexander at ſome moments, and at others have no propenſity to moleſt even a mouſe? No man in England is at this inſtant leſs inclined to miſchief, murder, and bloodſhed, than I am.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Then you have no inclination to die like a Hero, that you may live for ever?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Not the leaſt in the world as I hope for mercy—my thoughts are all turned to tranquillity—Peace—peace and quietneſs is my wiſh—and, when one conſiders, that—that now is really a moſt virtuous diſpoſition—Why ſhould I cut any man's throat? Or why ſhould any man cut mine?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: How will Anlaff underſtand that logic▪ when he finds that you are the perſon who kill'd his brother Alric?

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I didn't, Fool, I didn't.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: No—Thank heaven I have not that ſin to anſwer for—I kill'd nobody—"Nay more"—I never kill'd a man in my life.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Never kill'd a man in your life!

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Zounds, what a ſhame that is!

sp.speaker: E. Eg
sp.p: And I ſhall think it exceedingly hard if any body kills me. Oh Lord! What is that!
sp.stage: [Shouts, and founding of the bugle born is heard.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, it is the Danes—What ſhall I do? I tremble all over—ſhale like a cobweb in a high wind—my imagination is haunted by ten thouſand furious figures of bloody-minded Danes▪ I ſhall certainly be murdered
if I don't keep out of the way, [looks] Hark! [Noiſe again and born] They are entered! [Noiſe] Aye, aye, they are at it—I'll hide myſelf in this corner till their firſt fury is abated [Gets beneath the armour] Oh that I could go to ſleep!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Where can this vaunting coward▪ this ignominious Earl have hid himſelf?—Hark you, ſirrah, do you know any thing of! all Egbert?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I know Earl Egbert, Sir!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of him, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, many things—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I perceive by your countenance and equivocation you know where he is, and if you won't tell me peaceably, I will take you by the heels, and ſhake the ſecret out of you, ſirrah.
sp.stage: [Leonard lays hold of the Fool, who immediately points to the place where E. Egbert is concealed]

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Sir—if you were to ſhake my ſoul out of me, I would not ſay a word.—Nay—kill me if you pleaſe—ſeparate me like an opened oyſter, but I won't ſpeak.
sp.stage: [The Fool keeps pointing till Leonard goes and overturns the armour, and diſcovers Earl Egbert.]

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Be gone, ſirrah. [Exit Fool.]

div.head: SCENE V.
div.p: Thou ſhameleſs Lord! thou diſgrace to honour—But I have no Time to waſte with a Thing ſo bale and inſignificant.—Riſe—liſten and obey.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I will, good Sir, I will—what would you pleaſe to have me do?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Anlaff, the Dane, has ſent a Herald with a challenge.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Oh Lord! a challenge! To whom, pray'

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
To the man who vanquiſhed his brother Al •••• the conditions 〈◊〉 , Anlaff will give hoſtag • s that i • he
be conquered, the Danes immediately ſhall quit the caſtle; but if he conquer, the life of his enemy ſhall remain in his power, and Edwitha be given for his Bride.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Lord Sir! what's all this to me? You know I never killed Alric his brother, and you or he are very welcome to the lady.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hear me, wretch!

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Go to Earl Walter—and with your yeſterday's confidence profeſs yourſelf the Vanquiſher of Alric, and the Foe of Anlaff—Then ſend your own armour hither by your Dwarf, together with the ſword and ſhield you ſo valiantly took from the dead Alric; and after that, go hide—hang yourſelf—only be ſure to keep out of ſight.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: That, Sir, at leaſt you may depend upon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Away then—You are ſafe, therefore ſwell, and look important.—Dare not to fail—obſerve me—on your life dare not to fail.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I will endeavour, Sir, to obey.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This Reptile almoſt makes me forget, reſpect, and aſſume a chacter I deteſt.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: What are you determined, Leonard, to fight the Dane?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: But wherefore do you take the diſguiſe of that cowardly Earl?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why aſk you that?—you know it is a condition in the challenge of the haughty Anlaff, that he will not debaſe himſelf to fight any whoſe birth and origin are obſcure or mean.—"Beſides—I—but 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p:
Well Leonard, there is not an arm on earth I would more gladly commit the protection of every
thing moſt dear to, than to thine.—And yet—I am not without fear—The Dane is a bold, and almoſt matchleſs Warriour—Never yer equalled by his moſt renowned or deſperate Foe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: "Aye!"—But I have a cauſe would nerve an Infant!—Edwitha! Love! and Edwitha!

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Love and Edwitha! you rave, Leonard—And yet impoſſible as it is that love like this ſhould be ſucceſsful, I almoſt rejoice at it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Aye, 'tis a noble paſſion, that adds ſtrength and dignity to courage, gives magnanimity to the lover's enthuſiaſm, and makes the young Hero more than mortal.—But we talk too long—Have you informed and cautioned our companions?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I have—their hearts and prayers are with you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Away then, good Adam, watch the behaviour of that fooliſh Earl, and confirm him, if you ſhould perceive him faultering.—Hole—take this Letter, and find ſome private way of conveying is to Edwitha, before we enter the liſts.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Well, Leonard— • e firm—be reſolute—be—yourſelf—Farewell.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Farewell!—I go, determined, to a glorious Victory!—or a glorious Fa •• !

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter Clym o' the Clough, and Will. Cloudeſlee.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Welcome, my friends, every thing conſpires to procure our pardon. We have only to ſight bravely, and ply our bows as formerly, and we ſhall become ſons of grace and favor.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Why look you, Adam, you know me—I am no Flincher—I conquer, or—or there's an end of me—that's all

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And a dead man, Clym, don't value an angry King.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: Right, lad.—He that fights and wins, may ſup in peace.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And he that fights and dies, don't want any ſupper.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: We ſhall have warm work.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: It's not the firſt time I have been in danger.

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: He that never was in danger, never knew the ſweets of ſafety.

lg.l: When, o'er the World, the playful Lamb
Hath, till the duſky twilight, ſtray'd,
His tender plaints cry Here I am
Of night and ſolitude afraid.
But if, far off, his Dam he hears,
Echoing oft the mournful bleat,
He runs, and ſtops, and hopes, and ſears,
And bounds with pleaſure when they meet.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, my lads, ſince reformation's the word, why I 'll reform; we have ſpent many a merry day together, but if they pardon an treat us like men, why ſo—if not—

sp.speaker: Clym.
sp.p: If not, Will, I am an outlaw again.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And I▪ by this right hand.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: And I—But ſear it not—they are noble, and we are brave.

div.head: ANCIENT GLEE, compoſed in the year 1500.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: We three Archers be,
Rangers that rove through the North Country,
Lovers of ven'fon and liberty,
That value not honours or money.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: We three good follows be,
That never yet ran from three times three,
Quarter-ſtaff, broad-ſword, or bow-manry,
But give us fair play for our money.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: We three merry men be,
At a laſs or a glaſs under green wood tree;
Jocundly chaunting our auncient Glee,
Though we have not a penny of money.

div.head: SCENE VIII. Changes to the Court-yard of the Caſtle.
div.stage: Enter Earl Walter, Earl Egbert, Dwarf, Saxon Herald, Edwitha, Adela, and Adam Bell.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: You have heard, brave Egbert, the challenge of the imperious Anlaff, and the threat of inſtant ſaccage, if refuſed. You ſee the almoſt impoſſibility of our making a ſtand againſt his multitudes, and you know the perſonal proweſs of the Dane. Put therefore all conſideration of the particular ſafety of me or mine aſide.—Conſult your own feelings, and let them alone direct you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Heavens! How I tremble.—He ſurely will not dare to accept the challenge.— [Aſide to Adela.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Will he drink boiling Lead doſt think? or ſtand a tiptoe on a church Steeple?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: You know your leſſon; ſpeak confidently.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: My Lord—hem—I—Are you ſure the youth dare fight this Anlaſt? [Aſide to Adam Bell.]

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Yes—And I am ſure the youth dare cut your throat if you don't leave your quaking▪ and ſpeak in your other voice.—Come Sir,—mouth a little.—Utter your big breath. [Aſide to Egbert.]

sp.speaker: E. Eg
sp.p: Hem! My Lord—hem—deeds done in open day—muſt ſee the light.—That I have done the deed which doth ſtir the gall of the angry Dane is notorious and paſt recall.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Doſt hear Adela? He is going to pronounce my condemnation. [Aſide]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Pooh—ſilly—doſt thou not know him? 'Tis all flouriſh.—One bright blaze, and the ſnuff is out.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Alric is dead.—Swelling renown ſits perched upon my Creſt.—Anlaff would pluck it thence and tranſplant it to his own.—Anlaff—is mighty in ſtrength—in bone—in ligament and ſinew awful!—I am—but as other men.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Ay—Think of that, good Earl Egbert, remember that.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I—I do—I do.—Were I to compare myſelf to the Dane,—my wriſt to his,—my leg,—or eſtimate ſucceſs, by breadth of back—

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: And how elſe, would you eſtimate my Lord? you have no charm, to make yourſelf invulnerable.—Blows—wounds,—and death—muſt determine the fearful Conflict—If you once pronounce the dreadful yes, fight you muſt—there is no retreating—and die you muſt, unleſs you conquer.—Anlaff will never forgive his brother's death.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Thanks dear girl.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Fear nothing—obſerve his lip; that proclaims his thought.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Why—theſe—theſe—a—'tis true—are circumſtances, that will obtrude upon the fancy in Valor's ſpight—and therefore—it will argue prudence in me to decline the combat. [During the next ſide ſpeeches, Earl Walter ſeems engaged in ſpeaking to the Herald, and Adela and Edwitha with each other.]

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: S'death! what do you mean? accept the challenge inſtantly—Shake off your fears, and appear confirmed, or by heaven I 'll ſtab you—What ſheep you are not to fight. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: I had forgot—I will, I will [Aſide.]—I ſay My Lord.—Or I meant to ſay,—Theſe circumſtances weighed might induce, a—a cautious man to turn recreant, and decline the deſperate conteſt—but no—

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I am loſt.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: No, no, no!—I am fixed—immoveable—determined.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Sir—proceed.

sp.speaker: E. Eg.
sp.p: Away Herald, and hurl defiance forth.—Tell the mighty Anlaff, that Egbert the Valiant, who ſlew Alric the Cruel, will meet him inſtantly. [Exit Herald, Earl Egbert, and Adam Bell.]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Why then the die is caſt,—and I am the devoted victim.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Patience! Is it poſſible! It cannot be that he dare meet Anlaff! "the Daemon of temerity poſſeſſes him"—My Lord you will be ſhamed, diſgraced for ever—my couſin ruined—

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, Niece.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: No, Uncle—'Tis you are miſtaken—That braggart, that bubble will burſt, and leave an everlaſting ſtain upon your houſe, your happineſs, and honour.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: I confeſs I have my doubts: I did not like his behaviour, and deſperate as our condition is, I even hoped he would refuſe, but I could not honourably controul his choice.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, your ſon young Harold, and all his Knights, are haſtening to your relief.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My brother! Is he arrived?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Half an hour will bring him to the liſts.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Happy tidings! Delay the fatal trial my Lord, and ſave my Edwitha!

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Oh! that I had the power—But—it muſt not be—my honour is pledged—the combat muſt proceed—Would he had arrived but one ſhort hour ſooner!

div.head: SCENE XI.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Why this is madneſs!—My poor Edwitha!—ſurely men have conſpired thy deſtruction!—This Coward! this Thing! this Egbert!—But it cannot be!—What, a fellow that faints if he cuts his thumb—that • i • s trembling at an old woman's tale of a ghoſt—that dare not ſleep in the dark—and that would run away from a coat and a hat hung upon a broom-ſtick to ſcare crows! He fight Anlaff! he!—Why didſt not ſee how he ſhook!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: It is i •• ed moſt unaccountable. The fear of reproach may, perhaps, for a moment have overcome his other fears: Be it as it will, there is now no hope for me, and I have only to prepare, and meet my fate becomingly.

lg.l: The rill that from the ſteep aſcent
The mountain pebble waſhes white,
Mournfully murmuring, as 'tis bent
In ſearch of reſt, with anxious flight:
That rill, e'er to the ocean borne,
Shall ſooner from its motion ceaſe,
Than my poor heart ſhall ceaſe to mourn,
Than my poor heart regain its peace.

sp.p: I apprehend the worſt, and go with a mind calmly fortified, and a patient reſignation to my fate

div.stage: An arrow drops at the feet of Edwitha with a letter.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What is this, Adela? An arrow and a letter? [reads.]
sp.q: To the faireſt of Earthly beauties the Lady Edwitha.
sp.p:
Gentle Saint, Let your holy wiſhes and fervent prayers be offered to the giver of victories, for—Leonard the Peaſant!— [Edwitha looks up at
Adela almoſt overpowered, but with great expreſſion—reads again] Who is ſoon to be engaged in all the hazard oſ mortal ſtrife, for the moſt virtuous, worthy, and accompliſhed lady of the World.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: [After a long ſigh] Oh my poor heart!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: [With her eyes fixed] Why what is this! What aenigma!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: A Miracle! A Man! A Hero! A Demigod! Had heaven granted me a Wiſh, this ſhould have been the firſt! That he may be victorious is the ſecond. [With great fervour.]

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh, Adela! But now I was acquieſcent in the worſt of fortunes; had forbad my heart to flutter, reaſoned irregularity from my beating pulſe, and ſoothed my troubled paſſions into apathy—And now—in an inſtant, with increaſing violence, they are all returned, and overwhelm me with a ruſhing tide of fears.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Fears! Hopes! Extacies! Unexpected Raptures!—Why girl, thou art as one ſuddenly caſt from a precipice, whom a protecting Angel hath caught falling, and winged to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Why look thee, Adela—behold the good proportion, the big ſtature and haughty confidence of the Dane.—Is he not an enemy to be feared?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: He may be matched.— [Trumpet again.] Yonder is one coming, will teach him humility.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Nay, but is not that Earl Egbert's armour, Adela?

sp.speaker: Ade
sp.p: Yes, the caſe is his— [Leonard enters, the Ladies are on the farther ſide from his entrance]—but obſerve the ſtep—the geſture, and the form—look at the modeſt manly air with which it moves; then tell me, though it be the Shell of Egbert, is it animated by the Soul of Egbert, think'ſt thou?
sp.stage: [Leonard bows with a modeſt reſpect as he paſſes, then turns with an attitude of hope and admiration, and goes off to the combat.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Oh brave, brave youth!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: The ſmiles of Heaven, and the ſtrength of Lions go with him!

lg.head: I.
lg.l: When Scorching Suns the thirſty Earth
Of all her treaſures drain,
The Roſe, of Summer's lovelieſt birth,
Droops on the languid plain.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But when refreſhing rains deſcend
Again the Verdure ſhoots;
Again reviving Nature ſends
Her gifts of flowers and fruits.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The heart exhauſted thus, depreſs'd,
A prey to ardent Woe,
Revives and ſmiles, when Joys ſo bleſt
Once more unhoped for flow.

div.head: SCENE XII. Changes to the Hall.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: So, Dwarf, I would adviſe you to pack—I would counſel you to be gone—you and your thrice valorous Lord—ſteal off—now, while the hubbub of Contention ſhall cover your retreat—or you will both die by the diſhonourable diſtaff—Be adviſed, I ſay, and run—ſcud—ſcamper—ſkulk.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: Think you my honourable Lord will take a Fool's advice?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No—he never takes your's—But go—tread, trainple, traverſe, trot, travel, trundel, trip, troop, trudge, I ſay, with trepidation. [Exit Dwarf.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: The combat is going to begin, and we ſhall have hopes and fears, and aching hearts, and ſtreaming eyes, and ahs! and ohs! and hurra's! in plenty—It's a great happineſs I am a Fool, otherwiſe theſe things would make me melancholy—But ſinging and joking is a merry trade, and I ſhould be a Fool, indeed, to forego the beſt perquiſite of my place—No—let them them fight that will—I'll look on.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: For were a man melancholy
At proofs of others folly,
His days would be waſted wholly
In moaning out oh, oh:
His cares each moment heaping,
His nights all ſpent in weeping,
He'd want time to eat or to ſleep in,
For his tears ſhould eternally flow.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Then let 'em fight and quarrel
For Wealth, or Wench, or Laurel,
Pretending they abhor ill,
Yet I'll laugh out ah, ah!
He that wears the longeſt rapier
Let him make his enemy caper,
And his ſoul fiz forth like a vapour,
My trade ſhall be ſtill ha, ha!

div.head: SCENE XIII. and laſt.
div.stage: The Liſts, Daniſh Knights, &c. arranged on one ſide, and Archers on the other. Earl Walter, Edwitha and Adela ſeated on a kind of throne, as near the front as may be. Leonard and Anlaff armed with ſword and target. Two Heralds, one Saxon, the other Daniſh. Trumpeters.

sp.speaker: E. Wal
sp.p:
Mighty Anlaff, let me demand on the part
of your antagoniſt, what is your cauſe of quarrel, and the motive of your preſent challenge?

sp.speaker: Anl.
sp.p: Revenge for a dear brother, baſely ſlain, and reparation for a rude denial to an honourable propoſition.—Briefly, I ſeek to win Edwitha, whom I vehemently love, and puniſh Earl Egbert, whom I as deadly hate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I demand to know the challenger's ſource of enmity to Earl Egbert.
sp.stage: [Earl Walter is ſurprized to hear it is not Earl Egbert who ſpeaks.]

sp.speaker: Anl.
sp.p: Inſolent Lord, I have ſaid—thy proclaimed death of Alric.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Then is thy enmity miſplaced—For not Earl Egbert, [lifts up his beaver] but I, Leoline, the Briton, ſlew thy brother.

sp.speaker: Anl.
sp.p: Leoline! [amazed.] Prince of the Britons!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: In defence of that moſt chaſte and beauteous Lady, I ſlew him; and again, in her defence, here do I ſtand in thy defiance, proud Dane; nay further do proclaim my Love for her with a tongue as loud as thine, but with a heart, I hope, leſs arrogant.—Now, if thou haſt a ſoul worthy of ſuch moſt matchleſs Excellence, let it rouſe up every latent faculty, and fill thee with the divine furor of courageous Love.—Behold—look upon that lovely, that ineſtimable Prize, and be thou equal to a contention ſo exalted—Come—
sp.stage: [The trumpets ſound the charge.—The combat:—during which, Edwitha and Adela are greatly agitated. Several turns in which the Cambatants are each in danger, at laſt Leoline falls on his knee, Anlaff runs furiouſly at him, he ſprings on one ſide, averts the blow, and ſuddenly diſarms the Dane. Shout.]

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: There, Sir, are your arms.—Agreeably to your own condition, your life is in my power—but I do not thirſt for blood.—To repel lawleſs force, and redreſs the Injured, is the extent of my ambition.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment, noble youth, and joy almoſt deny my tongue the utterance of my full heart's gratude—ſpeak—ſpeak—Edwitha.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I cannot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Beauteous Edwitha, why I have appeared in a ſhape and character ſo ambiguous ſhall be the queſtion, I hope, of many a happy hour.—It was indeed to gain your true affection—not as a Prince, who could confer, but as a Suppliant who beſought your favour,—and ſuch let me ever continue.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Why am I ſilent?—Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I could not come, my Lord, proud of my birth, and heralding, my titles, to claim a jewel ſo ineſtimable, ſo much above the price of Kings, or Kingdoms.—No, Edwitha, though I love you to diſtraction, could I not firſt have won your heart, I never would have aſked your hand.—My fixed paſſion, would have deſcended with me to the grave, but never ſhould have troubled your repoſe.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: You tell us, my Lord, how much you are in love, but not how you became ſo.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The fame of Edwitha's beauties, her virtues, and the rare endowments of her mind, of theſe I had often heard. At laſt a Knight, who had met courteous entertainment, from my Lord her father here, deſcribed her wit, her gentleneſs, and charms, with ſuch enraptured words, I could no longer reſiſt the ſecret wiſh to behold her, which from the moment when firſt I heard her praiſe, I had ever cheriſhed.—That my love has been ſucceſsful, is the happineſs and glory of my life.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Do not, generous youth, thus over-rate what you ſo kindly think valuable, left hereafter you ſhould find me far—far leſs deſerving, and I ſhould loſe your Love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, Edwitha—you have a native dignity of mind incapable of degradation or alloy.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, I will at leaſt endeavour to be what you kindly think I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My honour'd Lord, and Father, as I hope.

sp.speaker: E. Wal.
sp.p: Willingly, my Lord—you have given me life and honour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Adam, and my brave Aſſociates, now no longer Outlaws, you ſhall be my Soldiers, and become true men as well as valiant.

sp.speaker: Om Ar.
sp.p: Thanks noble Prince.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Sir, we will ever love and ſerve you faithfully—Alice, Thou art a true-hearted Laſs, and ſhalt liſten at night to the tale of thy bonny Adam Bell.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Then I ſhall be the happieſt Laſs in England.

lg.l: Come, come with ſongs of mirth and joy,
Let's celebrate the day;
Sing ſweetly to the am'rous boy
A dulcet Roundelay.
And you who hope ſuch bliſs to prove
Our moral make your care,
Nor till your hearts are worthy love
For love's Delights prepare.
